title: Monday Morning Business Brief
text:
October 19, 2015, 6:38 AM TOKYO - 
European stock markets were mostly higher in early trading today while Chinese markets zigzagged after quarterly growth figures countered pessimism about the world's No. 2 economy. Other Asian markets ended little changed. Futures point to a flat opening on Wall Street. Benchmark U.S. crude oil slipped below $47 a barrel. The dollar slipped against the yen and the euro. BEIJING (AP) - China's economy experienced a slowdown in the third quarter but the results are slightly better than expected. Stronger spending by consumers who are emerging as an important pillar of growth helped to avert a deeper downturn. The world's second-largest economy grew by 6.9 percent in the three months ended in September, the slowest since early 2009. WASHINGTON (AP) - Cybersecurity company CrowdStrike says China is still trying to hack American corporate intellectual property despite an agreement not to. The company's analysis suggests that China almost immediately began violating its newly minted cyberagreement with the United States. The company says it documented seven Chinese cyberattacks against U.S. companies. RIYADH, Saudi Arabia (AP) - Saudi Arabian Oil Co. says it foiled a fraud attempt involving scammers pretending to work for India's state-owned Oil and Natural Gas Corp. The statement follows a newspaper report claiming the kingdom's oil firm was the victim of a massive cybercrime. Saudi Aramco said the fraud involved a fake money transfer. The Indian Express newspaper last week claimed that Saudi Aramco paid out 1.97 billion rupees ($30.3 million) to the fraudsters. TEHRAN, Iran (AP) - Iran's vice president says his country is preparing for a "tsunami" of foreign tourists as Tehran and world powers are set to begin implementing a landmark nuclear deal that will lift sanctions in return for curbs on Iran's nuclear program. The official, who is also Iran's Cultural Heritage, Handicrafts and Tourism Organization chief, says President Hassan Rouhani's moderate policies and the easing of visa rules are reopening the door for tourists.
